title: heatwave-six-ways-cool-house---common-mistakes-avoid
story: It might be hotting up outdoors -butyoursquore stuck inside and struggling to keep cool, there are a iety of things todo to make your room cooler.Weve put together a handy heatwave guide to help.Close the curtains and windowsAlthough the first thing you might want to do on a warm and sunny day is to open the curtains and let some air in through the windows, this can sometimes make a room hotter.If the temperature is hotter outside than inside, then you could just be letting warm air in.However,you do open the windows, try to do so in a way which will encourage a through draft.Opening a lower window from the cooler side of your house and an upper window from the hotter side can help, making sure that all doors and windows are open from one end of the house to the other in order to let the air easily move through.During the night, the temperature tends to fall, soitrsquos possible, open your bedroom window a little to let a cooling breeze in as you sleep.Hanging a wet sheet in front of an open window can also help to bring the temperature in the room down.Turn the lights offLights can emit extra heat that can make your room warmer, soitrsquos not dark outside, turning them off can help to keep a room cooler.Turn electrical appliances offSimilarly to light bulbs, electrical appliances radiate heat which can make an already warm room even hotter.Unplug your phone, TV and other devices that may be radiating heat and donrsquot charge them overnightyoursquore trying to keep cool as you sleep.Use cotton or linen sheetsIf your bedroom is warm and yoursquore finding it too hot to sleep, using cotton or linen sheets can help.This is because they are breathable fabrics and better at keeping you cool than materials such as polyester.This also counts for clothes, so wearing a cotton or linen top and trouser will be cooler than heavier fabrics.If you have time when changing your sheets, you can put them in the freezer for around  minutes beforehand, so theyrsquoll feel cool when you get into bed.Make sure you place your sheets in a plastic bag before putting them in the freezer to make sure nothing spills on them and that they remain clean.FanA fan can be a good way of cooling a room down, and is a popular choice with many when the mercury rises.Placing a bowl of iced water in front of the fan can also be an extra step in keeping a room cool. This will make the air feel cool as the ice evaporates.Avoid things that can cause humidityA hot shower, the washing machine and the dishwasher all produce steam which can cause humidity and make a room feel even warmer.Use them as little as possible when a room is already too warm.

title: scotlands-schools-return-7-key-points-parents-pupils-know
story: Thousands of pupils from across Scotland will be ing to the classroom this week for the first time since March.Schools across the country are set to reopen their doors full-time from August , with some local authorities opting for blended method until August .It comes as a recent survey suggests almost half of teachers do not think it is safe for pupils to .The NASUWT union questioned  teachers ahead of schools reopening this week.The survey found teachers are anxious about going back to work and have not been given enough information or time to prepare.A total of % of those questioned do not think it will be safe for pupils to , with % uncertain.But what should parents and pupils know ahead of the t to the classroom Heres seven key points:Social distancing:There should be no requirement for physical distancing between pupils of any age.However where possible, secondary school pupils should physically distance where possible - being asked to refrain from close contact including hugs and high-fives.Pupils should not sit face-to-face at shared desks.Adults teachers will be expected to stay m from pupils other adults wherever possible.If yoursquore worried about your child going back to the classroom, National Clinical Director @JasonLeitchhas explained what schools and nurseries are doing to keep children safe and what you can expect when they get there.Find out more ## https:t.co MurxrqrqIpic sVMvVUmdash Scottish GovernmentAugust , Face coverings:PPE will not be needed in most schools, unless required by a risk assessment.Pupils will not be required to wear a face covering, but anyone wishing to do so should be allowed to.Where staff cannot maintain a m distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained period of around  minutes or more, a face covering should be worn.A changed day:Some schools and local authorities may opt for staggered start and end times to allow for less crowding as parents drop off and collect their children. Your local authority should contact you regarding this.Likewise, lunch hours and class times may be staggered to allow for less crowding in corridors and canteens.Assemblies will also be cancelled, with PE classes only taking place outdoors.School transport:Dedicated school transport should be treated as an extension of the school estate - meaningenhanced cleaning ofvehicles, and the inclusion of hand sanitising before boarding.Distancing between pupils on dedicated school transport is not required ndash but adults should remain one-metre apart from others.Pupils on school transport do not need to wear face coverings, but adults should.,params: .pushAnyone travelling to school on public transport must follow the public transport guidance on face coverings and distancing.Pupils will not need to distance on school busesHygiene:A ldquorigorous approach to environment cleaning must be implemented to prevent the virus from spreading, according to the Scottish Government.This means pupils may not be allowed to bring in as many belongings as before.Enhanced hygiene measures must be practised, including:Extra time for pupils and staff to clean their hands with soap and warm running water or sanitiser when: they arrive at school,from breaks, change rooms and before and after eating.Provision of adequate hand-washing or sanitising facilities throughout the school estate.Arrangements to support young children and those with complex needs who may need assistance.Coronavirus testing:The Scottish Government says arrangements are in place to monitor developments and allow for a ldquorapid response to any cases of the virus.They say this includes ldquoenhanced surveillance arrangements, test and protect and outbreak management.Contingency plans:In the event of a national or local outbreak, schools may need to introduce their plans for blended learning or close temporarily to help control transmission.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government websitehere.

title: sqa-exams-u-turn---know-far-john-swinney-might-change
story: EDUCATION secretary John Swinney is to address anger over the exam results ldquoscandal in Scotland as he faces calls to resign over the saga.The Deputy First Minister is to set out a series of seps to address concerns on Tuesday, amid mounting criticism over the downgrading of pupilsrsquo results.But what is the anger all about  And what has John Swinney said about a potential U-turn Here, we detail out everything you need to know about the SQA exam results saga:Why are people annoyed With no exams sat this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, the Scottish Qualications Authority applied a methodology that saw grades estimated by teachers downgraded.Pass rates for pupils in the most deprived data zones were reduced by .% in comparison with .% for pupils from the most affluent backgrounds.Exams were unable to go ahead this yearWhat is the Scottish Government doing about it Education Secretary John Swinney is expect to perform a major U-turn in a bid to sort out the current situation.The Courier reports that Mr Swinney is set to announce changes to the grades appeals process for pupils, with officials said to be examining ways to automatically review the results of downgraded pupils without each having to lodge an inidual appeal.On #SQAResultsI have heard the anger of students who feel their hard work has been taken away from them and I am determined to address it.These are unprecedented times and as we have said throughout this pandemic, we will not get everything right first time.mdash John SwinneyAugust , In a statement released on Sunday, Mr Swinney said: ldquoI have heard the anger of students who feel their hard work has been taken away from them and I am determined to address it.ldquoThese are unprecedented times and as we have said throughout this pandemic, we will not get everything right first time."Every student deserves a grade that reflects the work they have done, and that is what I want to achieve.ldquoI have been engaged in detailed discussions over the way forward and I know that we need to act and act quickly to give certainty to our young people.ldquoI will set out on Tuesday how we intend to achieve that.How have pupils reacted to the results Across the country pupils took to protest the results both in person and through an online petition.So far nearly , people have signed the petition, which hit out at what it called a ldquoclassist marking scheme.More than , people have signed a petitionPetition founder Sarah McLauchlan said: ldquoResults should be based off personal performance and personal performance only.ldquoEvery child is dferent, so assuming just because they are from a deprived area they wonrsquot do as well and children from privileged areas will excel is biased and unfair.ldquoIt is completely unacceptable and wrong, especially when class should not be a basis for results which impact the rest of a childrsquos le.The petition can be found here.What have political opponents said Scottish Labour will this week table a motion of no confidence in Mr Swinney, who is also the Deputy First Minister, which will be supported by the Scottish Conservatives.Earlier, Lord McConnell, the former Labour first minister, issued a warning to Nicola Sturgeon and John Swinney over the exam results chaos, saying ldquoget it fixed or go.Lord McConnell said the fiasco which saw , pupilsrsquo results downgraded is ldquonot good enough for Scotland.And writing in the Sunday Times, former SNP minister Alex Neil said the Scottish Government ldquomust reverse the decisions it made about examination results that saw the poorest children in many of the most deprived areas downgraded on the altar of a manufactured algorithm prepared in secret.A Scottish Government spokesman said about three-quarters ndash , ndash of all grade estimates required no adjustment, adding that the SQA results ldquoshow a narrowing of the gap between the most and least disadvantaged young people attaining grades AndashC compared to last year, and to a level below the average for the last four years.Pupils protesting the exams scandalScottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said First Minister Nicola Sturgeon must remove Mr Swinney, saying she either ldquobacks Scotlandrsquos pupils or she backs an education secretary that has presided over this exams fiasco.,params: .pushScottish Labourrsquos education spokesman, Iain Gray, said Mr Swinney ldquoneeds to go, adding: ldquoItrsquos taken John Swinney five days to even admit this fiasco is his responsibility. The threat of a no-confidence motion has seen him finally accept the fact that he got this badly wrong.The Scottish Greens and Liberal Democrats have not saidthey will back the no-confidence motion.Scottish Greens education spokesman Ross Greer said he welcomed John Swinneyrsquos ldquoadmission that the Scottish Government got this badly wrong.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoAn admission of error is step one in resolving this major issue but the detailed solution is what matters.ldquoWhy we ever got into this sorry state is a question that needs answered too.

title: borders-book-festival-jonathon-porritt-talks-climate-change
story: THIS Sundaysees environmentalist and writer Jonathon Porritt joining the Borders Book Festivals online audience to talk about his latest book, Hope In Hell: A Decade To Confront The Climate Emergency.Porritt, , is one of the UKs leading environmental activists, whose roles have included chair of The Ecology Party , director of Friends of the Earth, and co-founder of Forum for the Future, a sustainable development charity.Author of nine other books, Porritt hopes his latestwill reach "a combination of dferent audiences", the most important of which, he says, is the young people who are inheriting the impacts of manmade climate change."My sense today is that young people are the ones who are really going to suffer most from the accelerating climate impacts that we are now witnessing," Porritt tells the Border , "and every single day for the whole of the rest of their lives will in one way or another be impacted by climate change."He adds: "I talk a lot in the book about what I call intergenerational injustice how one generation has basically made it practically impossible for the next generation to have the same prospects, the same expectations, the same hopes as previous generations have had."The book, which stresses the urgency of fighting climate change, is also aimed at the "weary environmentalists" who have "been plugging away" at campaigning and those, says Porritt, "who have no pre-existing knowledge or deep understanding of climate change, who I hope will be able to get stuck in really quickly and pick up everything they need to know within the first four chapters."Porritt has little time for the idea that human activity might not have had an impact on climate change, or that the subject is over-egged by the media or environmental activists.He says: "I dont believe there is any serious continuing debate about whether climate change is happening or whether its caused by our lestyles or our economy and I think theres less and less of a debate about it not being serious."I think thats symptomatic of a change going on in peoples minds because they can see the impacts of climate change."The veteran campaigner believes that any failure of iniduals to change their behaviour is not down to climate change denial but what he calls "disavowal" ndash "As in, I see this is happening but perhaps Im not the person who can make a dference, so I will continue to be a bystander rather than an active participant in addressing this challengersquo," says Porritt."The story of the next decade is getting more and more people to come away from that bystander role and to be prepared to get stuck in."And Porritt believes this "disavowal" is part of the reason governments can be slow to enact policies to combat climate change."Thats what makes it possible for the politicians to go on downgrading the signicance of climate change," he says.ldquoOur politicians are not in denial but they are absolutely not addressing it as the emergency that the science now tells us it is."And you can see that in the policies they brought forward in response to the pandemic ndash the build back better movement has actually just become build build build."The UK governments "classic failure of deeper political understanding" is one reason the countrys economy struggled during lockdown, believes Porritt.He says: "Instead of using this as a fantastic opportunity to show how we could have an economy that is prosperous but very low carbon all were doing is defaulting to exactly the same kind of policy growth band positions that we were in before COVID."Having had this shock, this really traumatic impact on our expectations of what a good le looks like, its incumbent on us to learn that lesson, and use it to help shape a more resilient and compassionate economy, one that is more mindful of environmental stewardship obligations for ourselves as well as future generations."And it is the future generations who Porritt sees pushing for change.He says: "It was so interesting when Greta Thunberg was here in the UK. I think it was Michael Gove who said, Your example gives us hope. And she instantly responded and said, We dont want your hope, we want clear, cost-effective but very radical policy responses to the climate change. We dont want you to be hopeful on our behalf, we want you to be active on our behalfrsquo.He concludes: "Would you not be annoyedyou were a young person who was suddenly confronted by the reality of climate change ldquoOnly to hear politicians say, Well, its dficult to address this, I think this is a challenge for future generations."It makes me feel pretty mad even at the advanced age of , when I hear politicians talking like that ndash its so complacent, its so self-indulgent, its so contemptuous of the interests of young people today."To see in Jonathon Porritt in conversation with journalist and broadcaster Sheena McDonald, go to bordersbookfestival.org online-event jonathon-porritt-hope-in-hellThe Borders Book Festival is sponsored by Baillie Gford.

title: craig-lowrie-completes-fundraiser-memory-late-sister
story: GALASHIELS man Craig Lowrie has completed his fundraising challenge ndash and he says the donations total is ldquounbelievable.Mr Lowrie has now run a dozen km runs during the Border summer festival season, having completed his final event in Coldstream on Friday ."It was always going to be an emotional run as it was the last one," said Mr Lowrie, of Selkirk, whose son Robbie was last yearrsquos Braw Lad in Galashiels.The challenge was created after this yearrsquos festivals were cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.Around pound, has been raised, according to Mr Lowrie, with the money going to the festival committees, as well as the Borders General Hospital.However, Mr Lowrie dedicated his efforts to his late sister, Donna Cameron, of Innerleithen, who died in a road collision last year, just two weeks before her nephews appearance as Braw Lad.Following the completion of the runs, Mr Lowrie said: "It was good to get them finished ndash the running was the easy bit.Reflecting on Fridayrsquos event, he added: "My sisters kids and husband were coming down, and apart from Innerleithen they had not been to any of the other runs."Mr Lowrie was due to be joined by his son in Coldstream, but Robbie had an injury which left him on crutches.But Mr Lowrie didnt run his last challenge alone ndash former Selkirk Standard Bearer Rory Monks joined in."Rory stepped forward to run with me," said Mr Lowrie. "I was glad to have the company as on my own it would have been gruelling."At the time of going to print, Mr Lowrie estimated that his fundraiser had reached a total of around pound, - with just over pound, being raised through his online Go Fund Me page."Its phenomenal, said Mr Lowrie. "I sat with Robbie at the beginning of the summer to talk about it."I didnt expect anything near what weve done ndash its unbelievable."Once he had completed his mammoth task, racking up more  kilometres across the summer, Mr Lowrie gave a speech to supporters through a Facebook livestream.In his speech, Mr Lowrie said: "Especially in these uncertain times we live in, you made the dference ndash I only ran."The comments you guys have posted each week ndash some heartfelt, some really encouraging, some quite funny ndash all really did mean a lot to me and gave me a great sense of pride."To support Craig Lowries fundraiser, visit his Go Fund Me page.

title: galashiels-pavilion-cinema-reveals-date-reopening
story: THE Pavilion Cinema in Galashiels will reopen to the public next week.The Market Street venue has been closed for the last five months due to the coronavirus pandemic.But film lovers will be able tonext Friday .Cinema manager Andrew Poole said: ldquoThe past few months have been the longest and hardest in our familyrsquos  years in running cinemas."But we have survived and we are ready to reopen, albeit under extraordinarily dficult conditions."When we reopen, we will have a range of measures in place to protect our customers including fewer performances to allow deeper cleaning of halls between shows, one-way systems at the concessions stand, perspex screens, hand sanitiser stations throughout the building and we will be adhering to the physical distancing rules in place at that time."We are able to ensure our customers are sat two metres apart in the cinema hall using our booking system."All customers are encouraged to book in advance, but tickets will be available at the cinema."Classic films will be shown at first, before Christopher Nolans Tenetis screened on August .Mr Poole added: "Films such as Peter Rabbit, Jumanji, The Greatest Showmanand Harry Potterwill play alongside Disneyrsquos Onwardwhich had only been showing for a week before we closed."We will also be showing Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back, currently celebrating its th anniversary."We havenrsquot been idle during lockdown. Wersquove carried out some refurbishment works including some repainting, and wersquove also just completed our pound, audio replacement project, replacing our entire audio system including sound processors, ampliers and speakers, upgrading to Dolby . surround sound."And wersquove installed the Dolby Fidelio system to improve access to film for customers who are hard of hearing or visually impaired."The cinema is also launching a Movie Party hall hire scheme, where groups of up to  can enjoy a film privately.Mr Poole said: "After five months of watching films on living room TVs, wersquore confident that our customers will be desperate to get out the house and see films on the big screen once again. Films are made to be watched in cinemas."And with the safety measures we will have in place, we think our customers will feel safe enjoying films where they are best viewed."

title: melrose-rugby-coaches-complete-41-mile-fundraiser
story: MELROSE rugby coaches completed a -mile exercise challenge at the weekend.Bruce Ruthven, Nicholas Alston and Blair Roden travelled from Moffat to Melrose on Saturdayby running, swimming, kayaking and cycling.The trio collected more than pound, for the Move With Mark fundraiser, launched in June by Lachlan Gaddie and his sister Hannahafter their father Mark was diagnosed with cancer.ldquoWersquore really delighted with how the whole day went, said Ruthven, Melrose RFCrsquos head coach.The Move With Mark challenge has now generated more than pound,, with donations going to the Borders General Hospitaland the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh.Car salesman Mark Gaddie, of Melrose, has been receiving treatment at the Edinburgh hospital five times a week. It comes a decade on from his wersquos death from cancer in the BGH.As part of the Move With Mark challenge, Lachlan and Hannah have each been covering . miles every day ndash and they have encouraged others to cover the same distance by swimming, running, cycling or rowing.Yet on Saturday, Ruthven, Alstonand Rodenstepped up to the plate and decided to set themselves the task of covering  miles.Beginning at Moffat Rugby Clubrsquos ground at am, they ran  miles to St Maryrsquos Loch.They then completed a one-mile kayak, followed by a -metre open swim and, lastly, a -mile cycle to Melrose via Selkirk and Abbotsford.ldquoWe had the run finished by .am, so we had probably the toughest part of the day out the way by lunchtime and then the rest of the day was really quite pleasant, said Ruthven, who lives in Peebles.The journey went by without a hitch, according to Ruthven, who expressed gratitude to the grouprsquos -strong ldquosupport team, as well as the dozens of well-wishers lining the route.ldquoThere must have been close to  people throughout the day following us, which really helped, said Ruthven.ldquoTheyrsquore quite winding and twisting roads but we had no issues whatsoever ndash it went really smoothly.He added: ldquoWe managed to complete the  miles in about six hours, which was the time we were aiming for.Ruthven said he came up with the challenge because of his desire to help Hannah and Lachlan. Lachlan plays rugby for Melrose.ldquoIt was really just to support Hannah and Lachlan who are going through a challenging and dficult time, said Ruthven.ldquoThe whole club got behind the challenge and Irsquod like to think thatrsquos a sign of things to come for Melrose Rugby Club. The support we had was overwhelming at times.To donate to the fundraising site set up by Ruthven, Alston and Roden, you can visit the lsquoMoffat to Melrosersquo page on JustGiving

title: eat-help-scotland---interactive-map-shows-50-discount-near
story: AN interactive map has been created to easily show the restaurants in your area offering a % discount.UntilAugust ,onMondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, restaurantsparticipating in the UK Governments Eat Out to Help Out scheme will offer half pricefoodand non-alcoholic drinks up to a total value of pound per person.Alcoholic drinks and service charges are excluded from the offer.Restaurants are offering % off foodThe initiative, launched by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, is encouraging peopleto support the hospitality industry by getting back to having meals out ascoronaviruslockdown measures are eased.In the first week more than  million meals were purchased as part of the new initiative.The Treasury said it had been sent ,, claims for inidual meals from restaurants as part of the Eat Out to Help Out programme.The interactive map showing locations within an area of GlasgowIt means that a maximum of pound. million can have been claimed in the first week of the scheme, which runs on every Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in August.The Treasury has put aside pound million to pay for the programme.The around , restaurants that have signed up to the Eat Out scheme so far take off % of a customerrsquos bill at the till and are reimbursed by the Treasury.How does it work You donrsquot need a voucher to use the scheme and you can use it at the same time as other offers and discounts. title: scotlands-schools-return-four-simple-tips-help-young-people-sleep
story: A charity has outlined four simple tips to help children and young people get to sleep now they have ed to school.For thousands of people across the country, this week marks their first time in a classroom since March.And with the pressures of ing to school and the drastic change from lockdown le, many might find it hard to fall asleep.Sleep Scotland, a charity organisation working to address sleep issues in children and young people, says that lockdown has resulted in youngsters experiencing poor sleep.Schools are back in Scotland this weekldquoThere are many factors affecting sleep but a crucial one is our Circadian rhythms, they said.ldquoOur circadian rhythms are the physical, mental and behavioural changes that follow a daily cycle.ldquoNearly every cell and tissue has its own rhythm, controlled by our biological clocks.ldquoIf our biological clocks are disrupted it can affect our circadian rhythms, and these changes have been linked to lots of other issues, including over activity, depression and obesity.They have set out four important factors for parents to pay attention to, in order to get your childrsquos sleep back on track for theto school.The four tips:Light#According to Sleep Scotland exposure to light at the wrong time can sht sleep and wakefulness - causing your brain to be alert.Their guidance says: "Make sure your room at bedtime is dark. Reduce light from the hall. Make sure there are no electronics sending out light e.g. a digital alarm clock with a lit display, sleep buttons on equipment etc."You may want to put black curtains at the window or wear an eye mask to limit the light getting into the eye."Sleep Scotland suggests wearing an eye maskOn the other end, you should also get lots of light in the morning to help you feel awake and alert.They added: "Exposure to light at the right time helps keep the circadian clock on the correct time schedule."Make sure you open the curtains and turn on the lightsyou need to. Going for a walk is a great way to start the day."RoutineIt is only natural that during lockdown many of us have found that we have lost our routine and have been staying up later and lying in bed longer in the morning.Sleep Scotland said: "Your body clock works best when you stick to a schedule."In an ideal world, yoursquoll go to sleep and wake up within a half hour of the same time each day, even on weekends."The routines of the day also give us powerful signals and demands that the body remain alert for certain tasks and events."Regular waking and bed times, alongside regular meal times are very important for regulating your body and its s."Sleep PressureSleep pressure is the term used to describe the feeling of tiredness we have, due to the activity we undertake through the day.,params: .pushSleep Scotland say it is important to be active in order to make sure we create the sleep pressure and drowsiness that will help us to fall asleep.They argue that having a nap can relieve our sleep pressure, meaning we find it harder to fall asleep at bedtime.Take a tech breakNaturally during lockdown many of us have resorted to using screens to help keep us entertained,to work and to socialise with friends.And while most modern tech has a blue light filter, it does not filter all light.More importantly, the things you do online are usually things that stimulate your brain and make it harder to turn off when you get into bed.Therefore, Sleep Scotland say you should unplug from all screens at least an hour before bedtime.They added: "In the hour before bed, ensure you focus on doing things that are calming."Now is the time to read, draw, do some calming exercises, have a warm bath etchellip"

title: selkirk-needs-20mph-speed-limit
story: A MPH speed limit should be introduced in Selkirk, according to some community councillors.During a video-conference meeting on Monday , Selkirk Community Council members discussed ways to reduce speeding in the town.David Deacon said: "We need to do something, rather than just talking."Treasurer Judith Thompson expressed interest in Selkirk becoming a ldquorsquos Plenty town.The national campaign, s Plenty For Us, aims to reduce speeds in residential and urban streets to mph.Community council secretary Kirsty Lovatt explained that she had previously been part of a similar campaign.She said she hoped s Plenty would be introduced in the town as it has "so many built up areas".Ms Lovatt also revealed that when she had previously begun the process of introducing the traffic measure, she was advised that it was unlikely to be possible in Selkirk.She said: "I was told it was too expensive to introduce new signage."During Mondayrsquos meeting, members all appeared to agree with the sentiment that there is a speeding issue in the town.And Scottish Borders Council representative Caroline Cochrane, who represents Selkirkshire, said: "Fleece Corner [A] is always a bad one [for speeding]."It was then proposed by Ms Cochrane that a stall be included in the next Selkirk Farmers Market, to be held on September , to gauge interest in supporting the move to a mph zone throughout the town.The community council agreed to work on the creation of a town petition ready for public viewing.

title: john-swinneys-sqa-u-turn-seven-things-need-know
story: John Swinney has announced today that the Scottish Governmentwill abandon the downgrade of more than , exams, with original teacher estimates insteadbeing used to determine this yearrsquos expected to jump by ., . and . percentage points compared to , rising to .%, .% and .% respectively.Will any grades be lowered The Education Secretary has said that no grades which were moderated to title: perseid-meteor-shower-2020-peak-week-best-time-spot
story: The Perseid meteor shower is expected to peak before dawn on Thursday as the Earth passes through a cloud of cometary dust - producing up to  meteors every hour.If skies are clear, the display of celestial fireworks should be visible across the UK from about midnight tonightuntil .am UK time on Thursday, August  - according to astronomers at Royal Observatory Greenwich.What are the Perseids The astronomical event is associated with the dusty debris left by Comet Swt-Tuttle, which orbits the sun once every  years.The meteoroids from the comet, mostly no bigger than a grain of sand, burn up as they hit the Earthrsquos atmosphere at  miles per second to produce a shooting stream of light in the sky.Peak temperatures can reach anywhere from ,C to ,C as they speed across the sky.The meteors are called Perseids because they seem to dart out of the constellation Perseus.The meteor shower began on July  and will continue to be visible until August .What have astronomers said Anna Ross, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory Greenwich, said the best time to spot the meteors is between midnight and .am on Thursday, when up to  meteors or ldquoshooting stars will be visible per hour, which is more than one every second.She told the PA news agency: ldquoThis makes the Perseids one of the most impressive meteor showers of the year.ldquoDuring the peak night of the shower, you will be able to find it in the north-east of the sky, getting higher throughout the night.ldquoYou donrsquot have to be able to see Perseus to spot meteors, however, as they will be moving away from the radiant across the whole sky in every direction.To make the most of the meteors, Ms Ross said observers should avoid well-lit and built-up areas and try to find an unobstructed view to the east.She added: ldquoFind a dark area and allow around  minutes for your eyes adapt to the dark.ldquoAs meteors move quite fast across the sky itrsquos best to look up without using telescopes or binoculars so you can see as much of the sky as possible.How regular will the meteors be The Perseids are one of the more active meteor showers on stargazersrsquo calendars, producing an average of between  and  shooting stars an hour at their peak.The shower in rsquos was especially active, delivering up to  meteors an hour at its height.While the shooting stars this year wonrsquot be quite as regular, stargazers can still expect to see around  of them an hour.Do I need special equipment to see the Perseids Meteor showers are typically visible with the naked eye, so no special equipment is needed, but those in rural areas with minimal light pollution will have a clearer view.Heading out to a dark spot is the best plan of action, but stargazers should allow around  minutes for their eyes to become accustomed to the dark.Patience is also a virtue, with shooting stars tending to appear in clusters, followed by a lull.The meteors will appear to come from the direction of the Perseus constellation in the north eastern part of the sky, although they should be visible from any point.A cloudy night could still scupper your chances of spotting any meteors, however, so keep your eye on weather forecasts.

title: confident-borders-schools-safe-says-council-chief
story: THE leader of Scottish Borders Council says she has "every confidence" that schools have been made safe amid the coronavirus pandemic.Yesterdaypupils ed to the classroom for the first time since March.And Shona Haslam believes all of the necessary measures were introduced before reopening.The member for Tweeddale East said: ldquoThis has been an extremely challenging time for us all and I know there is understandable anxiety in households across the Borders as our children and young peopleto school this week.ldquoAs a parent myself, I have experienced many of these within my own family."However, I have also seen just how hard staff teams from a range of services across the council have been working to make all our settings as safe as they can be, and have every confidence that this has been achieved.The local authority says part of the first few weeks of school will used to "help pupils with the transition back to the classroom".Mrs Haslam added: ldquoWe are extremely grateful to all our parents and carers for their support and co-operation throughout the past five months, not least with the requirement for home learning."Part of the adjustment that will be required over these next weeks will be supporting pupils with the transition back to classroom based learning in general, while taking into account the challenges that the pandemic has brought us.ldquoAdditional support will also be provided for those attending a school for the first time for P pupils and to help our new S pupils with their transition to secondary school.ldquoGoing forward, every effort will be made to make the school day and week as effective as is possible for everyone, while accepting that in keeping everyone safe it will be dferent to previous arrangements."I would ask for your continued co-operation and support for our staff as we do our best to achieve this.

title: borders-lockdown-stories-feature-new-book
story: A PEEBLESSHIRE writer has published a book filled with residentsrsquo stories about lockdown.Helen Holt, , started collecting stories for Peebles in Lockdownin May, and her little piece of history is now on shelves in a selection of local shops."I feel it was important to record [lockdown] in some way," said Mrs Holt, a freelance copywriter, going on to describe the project as ldquoreally satisfying.She added: "Im quite pleased with the final result."Mrs Holt said most of the contributions were of positive experiences during the pandemic, but she has ensured people know that this is not necessarily a true representation of every Peebles residentrsquos experience."I made a point in the introduction to say that there will have been negative experiences," she said.Peebles in Lockdowncan be found in Whities and as part of a lockdown exhibition at the Eastgate Theatre and other local retailers.Two hundred copies of Peebles in Lockdownhave been printed and distributed around the town.But Mrs Holt is willing to have another runthere is more interest.She said: "Ill restock as needed."People can leave their name with shops for more copiesthey run out."Although Mrs Holt has no immediate plans to create a second issue of her book, she feels the publication has shown Peebles in a "positive light"."This has confirmed that Peebles is quite a good place to live, she said.ldquoTheres a strong community spirit here."

title: rachael-hamilton-borders-msp-given-new-party-position
story: A CONSERVATIVE MSP for the Borders has been given a change of role within her party.Rachael Hamilton is now the shadow cabinet secretary for social security and older people.It comes in a reshuffle co-ordinated by Douglas Ross MP, the new leader of the Scottish Conservatives.Mrs Hamilton ndash the Holyrood representative for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire ndash said she is ldquodelighted about the role change.Mrs Hamilton was first promoted to the shadow cabinet in February when she was unveiled as the shadow cabinet secretary for rural affairs and tourism.

title: huge-asset-borders-closed
story: THE Girl Guide movement in Scotland has been left ldquoheartbroken after it was announced this week that its Borders-based activity centre would shut for good.The closure of Netherurd House near Blyth Bridge is said to be due to financial dficulty, with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic being the final nail in the coffin.Staff will be made redundant, with the exception of the groundskeeper who will be retained until the estate is sold.Margot Swanston, who has visited Netherurd for  years as a guide and leader, described herself as ldquodevastated.The stunning Georgian mansion and its extensive grounds have served thousands of guides and brownies for more than  years.After finances plummeted five years ago, a review was carried out which resulted in signicant investment to improve facilities and make it more attractive for users.There was an initial increase in bookings, but over the last three years numbers dropped, resulting in fewer users and financial woes.Girlguiding Scotlandrsquos chief commissioner Moira McKenna said: ldquoIn the past, we regularly used to fill the house with adults for county and other training weekends, but this has been declining for at least the last decade.ldquoFewer counties book for training, more of them come for only one night and the numbers from each county are lower than in previous times.ldquoThere is now much more training available online and this has increased dramatically this year with COVID-.ldquoEven before the pandemic came along, Girlguiding was planning to set up a digital hub to provide training online, and whilst we know the value of being together, volunteers across Scotland are finding the online or local training options more convenient in terms of both time and money.ldquoWe had hoped to build external business for mid-week, especially schools, but we were unable to build a wide enough business base to rely on this.ldquoEach year we have tried other avenues including holidays for Trefoil groups, retreats for local churches, private family gatherings and occasional weddings, but overall we could not generate enough routine business to help us improve the finances.ldquoThis was the situation before we were forced to close Netherurd in March due to COVID-, and since then the centre has had no income.A spokesperson for Netherurd House added: ldquoWe want to take this opportunity to say a huge thank you to all the staff and volunteers who have made Netherurd a place of adventure and provided ever-lasting memories for so many girls and young people.ldquoThis is a signicant loss to Girlguiding Scotland and we know many will be upset by this news.ldquoOur priority remains our members and wersquore committed to ensuring that girls and young women can keep having adventure and benefit from all that the outdoors has to offer.Former visitors to Netherurd House took to social media calling the closure a ldquosad day for Girlguiding Scotland.,params: .pushOne woman wrote: ldquoDreadful news. Broken-hearted doesnrsquot begin to describe the way Irsquom feeling. Netherurd has always been a home away from home to me.Joyce Sundstrem added: ldquoSuch sad news, an integral part of our Guiding over the years. Happy memories of training weekends and pack holidays there.ldquoItrsquos a shame to think the future rainbows, brownies and guides wonrsquot have the same chance to visit as we had.Many leaders and former users have described the news as a ldquodevastating tragedy for guiding and have even called for a rescue mission.Ms Swanston, the guidesrsquo assistant commissioner for Peebles, said: ldquoWe all hope it can be saved. I, as a guider, am devastated."I was  years old on my first guide camp and since then have stayed in the old Brownie house, the new Brownie house, and the big house itself.ldquoIt is not only a huge asset to Peeblesshire and the Borders, but to the whole of Scotland as it is the only residential venue owned by Girlguiding in Scotland.Ms Swanston and her family have strong ties in the Guiding movement and she says they have many happy memories of their time spent at Netherurd House.One cherished memory was formed only last October, when Ms Swanston renewed her Guide Promise after  years in Guiding.She added: ldquoMy granddaughter Megan took her Guide Promise for the first time and we were honoured by being enrolled by the Scottish Chief Guide.

title: peebles-family-walking-500-miles
story: A PEEBLES family are making the Proclaimersrsquo smash hit a reality by walking  miles.The McGrath clan are lsquogonna bersquo clocking up the miles this month for a brave girl who was born with a potentially fatal condition.Sandra McGrath said: ldquoCollectively we aim to walk  miles between st and th August and are well on track to smash that target.ldquoWe hope to raise pound, and, again, are already well up towards that total.The money will go towards the charity DEBRA, which funds research trying to find a cure for Epidermolysis Bullosa . The condition causes internal and external blistering.Sandra and her husband Mike were due to take part in the Great Wilderness Challenge in Wester Ross, alongside their daughter Sarah Keen and son Allan.Although the pandemic put the brakes on their plans, the family were determined to help DEBRA.The charity looks after -year-old Isla Grist, who lives near Inverness.Born at home, the paramedics who delivered Isla immediately rushed her to hospital where, for the first six months of her le, her parents Rachael and Andy carried her around on a pillow as the slightest knock or rub could tear her skin.Isla has had a painful le with endless visits to Great Ormond Street Hospital for treatments and operations.Every step, knock, or bumpcan cause permanent damage and her body is completely bandaged with thrice-weekly changes.Islarsquos plight is close to the McGrath familyrsquos heart, and for the last  years Mike and Sandra have been taking part in the Great Wilderness Challenge.Together with their extended family and friends, they raised pound, for the charity last year.Due to the events cancellation this year, they decided to fundraise with their own personal family challenge.Sandra said: ldquoWersquove done our walking running in the forests and hills around Peebles.ldquoAlso our son Allan McGrath, his we Rhona, and -year-old twins, Duncan and Isla, and -year-old Kirsty have taken part.ldquoThey did some walking around Edinburgh and are now continuing to complete their mileage from our holiday cottage in Gairloch, Wester Ross.EB affects every part of Islarsquos le and the family have had to adapt to a dferent kind of normal, like two trampolines ndash one for Isla and one for her sister Emily.And simply running around with friends is out of the question as it poses a danger to Isla.DEBRA is funding pioneering research into effective treatments and a cure for the condition.The McGrath family have proved they will walk  miles and more, just to be the ones to help Isla live the pain-free le she so desperately hopes for.

title: 10-mistakes-making-fridge
story: Recommendations are independently chosen by Reviewedrsquos editors. Purchases you make through our links may earn us a commission.There are right and wrong ways to store your food. For example, some food must be refrigerated while other types need to be kept at room temperature.Some cooking oils are fine on the countertop, and others should be stored in the fridge.Even some of your expired foods arenrsquot really expired, and you might be using the wrong containers. With food storage at a premium, you dont want to let anything go to waste.Wersquove done the legwork to figure out the right ways to store your food so that it tastes best and lasts the longest.Here are the answers to ten common kitchen storage mistakes.. Youre throwing out your lsquoexpiredrsquo foodCertain expiration dates have less to do with safety than they do quality. Credit: Getty   FangXiaNuoItrsquos important to know the dference between food that has passed the lsquoBest Beforersquo date and food that has passed the lsquoUse byrsquo date. You should never eat food that has passed its lsquoUse byrsquo date, but lsquoBest Beforersquo dates often reflect quality control, not safety or nutritional value. In determiningthe food that has passed the lsquoBest Beforersquo is safe to eat read up on Food Standards Agency guidelines, use your eyes and nose, and follow your gut.Smell:If it smells fine and it was stored properly, its likely okay to eat.Sight:Donrsquot let your eyes fool you when it comes to fresh food like produce. Bumps or bruises donrsquot mean something is ruined.Dont can the cans:Canned goods can last for decades. Even a can thats started to rust should still be okay, as long as it isnt bulging and the seal is intact.Check the packaging, use your senses, cook food thoroughly, and donrsquot let the perfect become the enemy of the good. A proper understanding of expirationdates could drastically cut down on food wastemdashnot to mention wasted money out of your pocket.. Youre using plastic wrap to save your leftoversBees Wrap can be used to store anything from biscuits to sandwiches. But not soup... yet. Credit: Bees WrapIf yoursquore sick of throwing away disposable food wrap but still want to keep food fresh, Beersquos Wrapmight be your answer. This reusable food wrap is made from beeswax and fabric.Itrsquos designed so you can build a sandwich on top of it in your kitchen, then unwrap it to use as a placemat. Beersquos Wrap is also ideal for food storage. An avid home baker, creator Sarah Kaeck said itrsquoll help keep bread crusty and soft. Itrsquos also great for wrapping cheese, half of an avocado, half of a lemon, covering jars and bowls .Afterwards, just wash it with cold water , hang-dry, and use it again. It should last about a yearyou use it a few times a week.. Youre refrigerating these foodsmdashand you shouldnt beNot everything goes in your fridge. Credit: Getty   SolStockSome foods are actively made worse by refrigerationmdashonions, potatoes, garlic, avocado, tomatoes, bananas, stone fruit, bread, pastries, melons, spices, honey, peanut butter, apples, coffee, eggs, butter, condiments, dressings, soy sauce and hot sauce should neverbe refrigerated. Surprised . You dont know how to store your cooking oilsSome cooking oils are best stored in the cabinet, while others can be refrigerated. Credit: Getty   Angelina ZinovievaCooking oils sourced from fruits, vegetables, nuts, and seeds each have dferent storage needs. Exposure to oxygen, light or heat will subject oil to oxidation, eventually turning it rancid. While some cooking oils can be stored at room temperature, others do best when stored in the fridge.Corn and rapeseed oils:These do just fine stored in a cool, dark cabinet, or you can refrigerate themit takes more than a year to get through a bottle.Olive oil:Leaving olive oil out on the counter or a table, especiallythe bottle gets direct sunlight, or storing it on or near a stove are surefire ways to turn it rancid quickly. Place it in the coolest, darkest place in your home or use a smaller glass bottle in the kitchen.Peanut oil:Can be kept for as long as two yearsstored tightly capped and away from heat and light. Keeping peanut oil in the fridge may extend shelf le even further.Coconut oil:Very stable andhas a shelf le of two years or more.Avocado, grapeseed, hazelnut, sesame, truffle, walnut, safflower and sunflower:Delicate oils that are especially prone to rancidity, especiallyexposed to too much light or heat. Refrigerating after opening is recommended. Kept cold, these oils will remain viable for six months or more.. Youre using the wrong containers to store your foodWe tested the best-selling plastic and glass food storage containers on the market to find the best of the lot. We dropped them onto a linoleum floor, froze them, microwaved them, stained them, pried them apart, stacked them back together, and lots more.Best glass container:Pyrexs Cook and Eat Glass Storage Setisa great choice. Food wont leak, and the glass wont shatter. While the BPA-free lids maystain, they will come clean after a run in the dishwasher. Therersquos a vent for microwave reheats and, as long as the contents are defrosted, itrsquos also preheated oven safe.Best plastic container:Rubbermaidrsquos Easy Find Lidscontainers wonrsquot spring a leak unless you shake them violently, and drops arenrsquot a problem unless the container happens to fall on its side or a corner. No plastic container is oven-safe, but the set is marked dishwasher- and microwave-safe and carries a letime warranty. You should avoid freezing this set, as expanding food may pop the lid.. Youre incorrectly storing fruits and veggiesDo you know which vegetables should stay at room temperature, which should be kept inside a salad drawer, and which should never be stored together  Are you sure Do not refrigerate:Potatoes, onions, garlic, winter squash, tomatoes, bananas, peaches, plums, avocados, mangoes, melons, apples, pears, kiwis, and citrus. Exceptions include freezing for smoothies, or refrigerating for brief periods when theyre close to spoiling.Keep separate:Produce that emits high levels of ethylene gas, including ripe bananas, apples, stone fruit , cantaloupe, honeydew melons, mangoes, pears, ripe kiwis, tomatoes, onions, and leeks.Store alone:Ethylene-sensitive produce, including aubergine, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cabbage, carrots, caullower, cucumber, leafy greens, peas, peppers, squash, sweet potatoes, strawberries, and watermelon.,params: .push. Youre letting your avocados turn brownThere are many ways to store a cut avocado, but only one that will actually keep it from browning and preserve the flavour: Leave the pit in an avocado, and tightly wrap the half in plastic wrap to keep the flavour and texture intact.. Youre letting the food in your fridge accidentally freezeFoods in your fridge shouldnt be freezing. Credit: Getty   IssaurinkoBiting into frozen food thatrsquos merely supposed to be refrigerated isnrsquot just annoying: Freezing can completely alter the taste and texture of your food. And itrsquos probably because yoursquore probably arranging your fridge the wrong way.Check your fridges temperature settings:The ideal temperature range for the interior of your fridge is degC and below.Determine problem areas:According to appliance manufacturer GE, the most common problem areas are the top shelf, the bottom of the fridge , and door shelves.Avoid vents:Most fridges have a cooling vent above the top shelf. This is where most of the cold air comes from, so keeping food away from here may prevent freezing. Adjust your freezer:Turn up your freezer temperature settings, but nothing north of degF, which will facilitate bacterial growth and accelerate food spoilage.Check your ice maker:Make sure that your ice maker is not constantly running. This could make your freezer too cold and subsequently cause your refrigerated foods to freeze.Stock up your fridge:Refrigerators need to be well-stocked to absorb all of the cold air being vented into the cavity. If it is relatively empty, all of the cold air will sink to the bottom of the cavity and freeze your food. A fully stocked fridge will help maintain temperatures and, as a result, use less energy.. Youre not fixing a door that wont shut properlyIf your fridge door wont close, its probably due to an old, dried-out gasket, the rubber seal that runs along its edge. Luckily, the fix is simple: wash the gasket, and apply petroleum jelly to the rubber to revitalize the old rubber.. Youre not regulating your fridges temperatureA full fridge will help keep the temperature consistent. Credit: Getty   Group StudioDid you know your fridge could actually be making you sick  To keep food out of what the Food Saftey Agency calls lsquothe danger zonersquo, it needs to remain below degC. The freezer should be set to -degC to keep freezer burn at bay. If your fridge and freezer are regularly warmer than those temperatures, yoursquore risking faster spoilage. Here are a few things you can do to keep your fridge properly chilled:Invest in a fridge thermometer.To use, place the thermometer in a cup of water. Why  Your refrigerator measures the temperature of the air around your food, but you want to simulate the temperature inside your foods. Check the thermometer after  hours and then, adjust the temperature of each appliance based on the results.Check to make sure the gasket is in good shape, and seals well.If you can open the door with one finger, your seal isnt tight enough. A leaky seal is an energy waster, and may be a risk to your food.Dust your refrigerators cooling coils,theyre visible. You can use a long, skinny brush made for this purpose.Cover your food.For example, leave eggs in their carton, not in the door.Keep a full fridgeto retain the cold, but leave enough room for air to circulate.The product experts at Reviewedhave all your shopping needs covered. title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: covid-19-recovery-queen-margaret-universitys-new-plan
story: Professionals educated in many of its key areas, from health sciences to the creative arts and social sciences, have already played key roles in tackling the pandemic.As the university launched its new Strategic Plan, which outlined its goals for the next five years, it was stressed that they would also be ldquovital to the global recovery.Highlighted were the graduates and staff who could already be found in positions all across the world, influencing policy, and enhancing society, culture and the economy. The university aimed to continue ldquoto make a real and immediate dference in the world, in keeping with its values.The strategy described how the university would contribute to societyrsquos ldquorecovery and recalibration following the coronavirus pandemic.It also set out how QMUrsquos ldquoperson-centred approach to learning made it ldquostand out from other universities, along with its ldquodistinctive academic portfolio and a focus on making society better.Through teaching, research and innovation, the university would further develop its work enabling people to ldquoheal, nurture, care and communicate, as well as inspire them to build and rebuild businesses, find solutions to real-le issues and to support communities. It would also build on its track record fostering creativity and artistic expression, building social and economic capital in the process.Sir Paul Grice, principal and vice-chancellor, said: ldquoOur new strategy holds true to the ethos of social justice on which this institution was founded. It sets out how we will nurture and build on our vital work improving society through teaching, research and innovation.

title: love-first-sight-couple-toast-golden-anniversary
story: Norman and Sophia Taylor enjoyed a socially distanced golden wedding anniversary, due to the Covid- restrictions, at their home on North Grange Avenue on July  with their three children.Northumbrian-born Norman, who turned  on June , met Sophia, , in Prestonpans Royal British Legion in , saying it was ldquolove at first sight and ldquoeyes over a dance floor.The pair married shortly afterwards at Prestonpans Register Office and then went on to travel the world due to Normanrsquos job as a fitter and turner, a trade he learned in the Merchant Navy.The family travelled across Britain between  and . They then stayed in Africa between  and , including Zambia, with the children attending public school in South Africa.However, Sophia started to feel homesick so moved back to Prestonpans in .Norman then got a job in Libya, working four weeks away and then being back at home for four weeks. He worked in this job for the rest of his career, retiring  years ago.During his working le, Norman was also a delivery driver.However, after his retirement he took on the role as a golf caddy at Muirfield, near Gullane.Prestonpans-born Sophia, as Cissie to her friends, worked as a barmaid, including at the former Lady Susan pub in Prestonpans.When Norman married Sophia, she had three children from a previous marriage: Richard, now aged , Charles, , and Eileen, .Their grandson Kal, described as the ldquoapple of their eye, was born in  and was ldquospoiled rotten according to Sophia.Norman and Sophia have sadly been in poor health recently, with Norman suffering a heart attack this year.However, he still makes an effort to visit the Legion in Prestonpans twice a week, every Monday and Friday.When the Legionrsquos beer garden re-opened and Norman was able to go back to his favourite bar, Richard said it was ldquothe first time I have seen a smile on his face for months.Norman says the secret to a long marriage is ldquothe we is always right.Richard added: ldquoThey are totally in love. Irsquove never seen my mum and dad fight and my dad has never risen his voice once. My dad is an absolute gentleman and they absolutely dote on each other.

title: lights-vandalised-andy-scotts-dunbear-statue
story: The steel sculpture, which features a bear standing on its hind legs and is located just off the A, near the Spott Roundabout on the edge of Dunbar, was unveiled last December.A post on social media revealed that lights next to the sculpture, which measures  feet in height, had been damaged.It reads: ldquoWe are conscious that a number of lights have been deliberately damaged at the DunBear sculpture and thanks to those for reporting this to us.ldquoWe have an engineer out looking at this.ldquoThe sculpture is very much part of the community and we would be gratefulyou see anyone damaging it that this is reported to the police.The artwork was created by Andy Scott, the same man behind The Kelpies, and is a tribute to Dunbar-born John Muir, who would go on to become a key figure in the formation of the US national parks.

title: musselburgh-library-offers-new-click-collect-service
